intro: Matelea riparia, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its large, white, fragrant flowers that open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant belongs to the Apocynaceae family, which includes milkweeds and related species. Matelea riparia typically grows in rocky soils and is often found in desert or semi-arid environments. Its unique blooming pattern and ecological role make it an important species in its native habitat.
